content: I love most elements of the game, including the combat, but the combat has one very big flaw: the way that turns are handled. This issue would be solved by allowing you to move ALL your characters on your turn, then the enemy moves all theirs. Like the way it's done in many other games.

Story is intriguing. Artwork is phenomenal. Music is epic and emotional. All in all, beautiful game with strategic game play. One thing that is missing is the dialogue tone and the facial expressions don't align at times. The characters have one facial expression and that's how they're shown throughout the game. Nonetheless, I really enjoyed the game. (Hint: max out the shield breaking ability in the characters that are good at it. Defeating enemies become easier, especially the stronger ones.)

There are so many things to love about this game. First, it's gorgeous. The Eyvind Earle-inspired, hand-drawn characters and backgrounds give the game a unique, beautiful look.  Second, the music is captivating from beginning to end. It's telling that the credits list many more musicians than programmers. Third, the story is well-written and the world and mythos built to support it are fascinating. It has so much potential that it left me begging to learn more. Fourth, the gameplay is straightforward to learn but still quite challenging. I had to play it through twice before I could beat it without turning down the difficulty. But I didn't mind, since there are so many different ways it can play out that it was fun to see how different choices affected my caravans. If "Lone Wolf" can be called a perfect blend of interactive fiction and action RPG, "The Banner Saga" can be said to be the perfect blend of interactive fiction and tactical RPG. One of the best I've played in a long time.

What a game. Simple to use yet actually challenging, it hold the player to real accountability that is so rare in games now. The story is a true gem, encompassing humanity in all its greatness and its atrocities. Here is a game where you revile a "hero" and sympathize with a "villain!" What a refreshing change! No boring post apocalyptic "i can survive everything because i am a special flower." This game is what the end of the world truly feels like, chaotic, ruthless, brutal, and painfully unfair. Yet, there are rays of hope here, with perseverance, stoicism, honor, and love. The battle system is quite a joy for a methodical thinker, yet may be too slow paced for those who crave nonstop stimulation. The artwork is rewarding enough that even after 20 playthroughs I still find details I have missed. Same goes for the story. This game is a gift that just continues to give again and again. I cannot recommend playing enough, especially to those who generally dislike video games. Bring on the sequel!

This is an amazing, fresh game, well worth the cost. People have compared it to Final Fantasy, but it's much more complex than that. I see it as sort of a mix of Final Fantasy, chess, and Tales of Illyria. Simply put, I've never seen a game like this before, and it's pure pleasure to play. The graphics are pleasant to look at, and the gameplay has just the right mix of depth and complexity along with simple fun and addictiveness. I am constantly tweaking my strategy. One particularly nice feature is the ability to change the game's difficulty at any time, allowing me to have a bit simpler play when I just want to relax (or if a particular battle is too challenging), and more complex play when I really want to dig in and challenge myself. I will probably play this game through multiple times to see the various story paths play out. Way to go, devs! Update: Played the game all the way through - now starting over to explore more story paths and work at various achievements. Best game I've played in a long time... Hope there's a sequel in the works!
